features.html:
Source 1

“The recent picnic which was held by the freedmen, last Saturday, the anniversary of the emancipation proclamation at the San Pedro Springs, was quite a grand affair, so we hear from different sources. Several hundred blacks were present on the occasion, besides a number of officers and soldiers of the army, and a few other citizens as spectators. A good deal of dancing was done by the freedmen, and a good deal...was drunk by the whole gathering, [and] some speeches were made.” 

Article in the Southern Intelligencer, a newspaper published in Austin, Texas, June 21, 1866

choicesHtml: African Americans’ celebration of Juneteenth showcased the high value they placed on their newly found freedom and the joy and validation they experienced among members of their own community.

African Americans’ celebrations of Juneteenth and other Freedom Days were primarily focused on honoring their ancestors and communal leaders who gave their lives in the struggle to end slavery in the United States.
The end of slavery created deep divisions among African Americans based on economic inequalities within their communities.
African American women were more frequently permitted to participate in celebrations of Freedom Days, as African American men were expected to work.
